user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls (size_t size,
                                                        const void *buffer,
                                                        MHD_ContentReaderFreeCallback
                                                        crfc,
                                                        void *crfc_cls)
{
  struct MHD_Response *r;

  if ((NULL == buffer) && (size > 0))
    return NULL;
#if SIZEOF_SIZE_T >= SIZEOF_UINT64_T
  if (MHD_SIZE_UNKNOWN == size)
    return NULL;
#endif /* SIZEOF_SIZE_T >= SIZEOF_UINT64_T */
  r = MHD_calloc_ (1, sizeof (struct MHD_Response));
  if (NULL == r)
    return NULL;
#if defined(MHD_USE_THREADS)
  if (! MHD_mutex_init_ (&r->mutex))
  {
    free (r);
    return NULL;
  }
#endif
  r->fd = -1;
  r->reference_count = 1;
  r->total_size = size;
  r->data = buffer;
  r->data_size = size;
  r->crfc = crfc;
  r->crc_cls = crfc_cls;
  return r;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The fragments selected are the conditional checks and guarded blocks that cause immediate returns or removal by the preprocessor; these are the places most likely to produce unreachable code in some build/configuration and therefore warrant investigation under MISRA C Rule 2.1. Other parts of the function (allocation, the NULL check of r, the final sequence of assignments and the final return) are normal, intended control-flow (error checks that return on failure, followed by the normal initialization path). There is no code textually following an unconditional return in the same block, and the remaining assignment/initialization statements are reachable when the function proceeds past the earlier error returns. Preprocessor-excluded code is not executed in that build, so only the reported conditional blocks need review for potential unreachable-code issues across project configurations.
